body_html:
Have a look a the full documentation of MaxUnpool. You first need to get the indices from MaxPool, and then pass those indices to MaxUnpool. For example:

out1, indices = F.max_pool2d(x, kernel_size=2, return_indices=True)
result = F.max_unpool2d(out1, indices, kernel_size=2, stride=2, output_size=x.size())

Note that you need to pass the stride parameter manually to max_unpool2d for the moment.
We should change a bit how we handle the default in max_unpool so that we don't have to pass the stride manually. I'll send a fix for it.

out1, indices = F.max_pool2d(x, kernel_size=2, return_indices=True)
result = F.max_unpool2d(out1, indices, kernel_size=2, stride=2, output_size=x.size())
Note that you need to pass the stride parameter manually to max_unpool2d for the moment.
We should change a bit how we handle the default in max_unpool so that we don't have to pass the stride manually. I'll send a fix for it.
body:
Have a look a the [full documentation of MaxUnpool](http://pytorch.org/docs/master/nn.html#torch.nn.MaxUnpool2d). You first need to get the indices from `MaxPool`, and then pass those indices to `MaxUnpool`. For example:
```python
out1, indices = F.max_pool2d(x, kernel_size=2, return_indices=True)
result = F.max_unpool2d(out1, indices, kernel_size=2, stride=2, output_size=x.size())
```
Note that you need to pass the `stride` parameter manually to `max_unpool2d` for the moment.
We should change a bit how we handle the default in `max_unpool` so that we don't have to pass the `stride` manually. I'll send a fix for it.
